awd_abstract_narration:
GENI, the Global Environment for Network Innovations, is a suite of research infrastructure that spans facilities across the United States. GENI aims to transform experimental research in networking and distributed systems, as well as emerging research into very large social-technical systems, by providing a suite of infrastructure for "at scale" experiments in future internets. Nationwide experiments began in Summer 2010. In the intervening five years, GENI has shown rapid growth in adoption by experimental researchers and is now expanding to over 50 GENI-enabled campuses.   In addition, via programs such as Campus CyberInfrastructure and US Ignite, GENI technologies are being actively used to advance national science capabilities and to imagine and design next generation applications that address national priorities.   Via commercialization of technologies such as Software Defined Networking and Network Function Virtualization GENI has had a significant economic impact.
 
This project supports the transition of GENI from a building phase overseen by the GENI Program Office (GPO) to an operational status managed by community organizations.  As part of the project, the GPO will broadly engage the U.S. computer systems research community to develop a community consensus-based plan for transition.   In conjunction with NSF the organizational structure identified by this plan will be established and GENI operations transferred with the project supporting operational expenses during the transition period.

Note: Multiple NSF awards have supported GENI. For context, this report summarizes overall GENI-related outcomes. This specific award, "GENI Going Forward,"  focuses on transitioning the GENI testbed and technology to the research community and incorporating GENI resources and concepts in current and future programs.

GENI's Goals

The Global Environment for Network Innovations - GENI - project has designed, built, and sustained a suite of research infrastructure comprising a distributed laboratory deployed across the United States. (See Figure 1.) GENI transforms experimental research in networking and distributed systems by providing infrastructure for "at-scale" experiments in future internets.

GENI supports a wide variety of experiments, including:

  • Experiments ranging from small to "at-scale" experiments.
  • Both experiments that are compatible and experiments that are incompatible with today's Internet.
  • Not only controlled, repeatable experiments, which which will greatly help improve our scientific understanding of complex, large-scale networks, but also trials of experimental services that ride atop or connect to today's Internet and that engage large numbers of users.
  • A variety of classroom and research experiments.

Although GENI is designed to support "at-scale" experiments on future internets, our plan has never been to build a separate, parallel set of infrastructure "as big as the Internet," which is clearly infeasible. Instead, the approach has been to "GENI-enable" existing testbeds, campuses, regional and backbone networks, cloud computation services, and commercial equipment to be programmable, virtualized and sliceable, so that they can support end-to-end experiments. 

GENI's Results

GENI has addressed its initial purpose of supporting innovative research and has gone beyond these goals in a number of ways. The GENI project office (GPO) and the GENI community have built GENI with an initial at-scale deployment now in place. GENI's use in the classroom lowers the barrier for laboratory-based learning in computer science education. It is increasingly finding application in data- and compute-intensive domain sciences. Furthermore, GENI infrastructure and concepts support advanced application development in areas of societal impact, through initiatives such as US Ignite. (See Figures 2 and 3.)

From its onset, GENI has seen explosive growth in usage for both research and education, quickly surpassing 14,000 unique users who have turned to GENI, allocating over a half million GENI configurations. (See Figure 4.) GENI's user base reaches more than 180 US universities and over 30 countries. (See Figure 5.) Educators continue to develop GENI-based curriculum and employ GENI in their classrooms. A typical academic year sees instructors using GENI in dozens of different courses with total enrollment of hundreds of students.

Under the GENI Going Forward (GGF) award, the GPO worked closely with NSF and the GENI community to ensure the sustained research contributions of GENI, first through support of its physical testbed, and later by employing GENI concepts and lessons learned in a number of successor and related mid-scale infrastructure programs. The primary responsibilities of ongoing GENI support transitioned from the GPO to a community-driven management model.

GGF also supported growth in international collaboration around network research testbeds. Building on an existing US/EU partnership, the GENI community has been a major force in the Global Infrastructure for Future Internets (GEFI) initiative, which has included representation from dozens of research testbeds across five continents. This group works together to facilitate research by combining and sharing concepts and testbed resources across international boundaries. As a result of GENI and many other collaborations, the central GENI notions of slicability and deep programmability are finding their way into future internet and distributed cloud research testbeds worldwide. (See Figure 6.) 

Future Directions

The GENI community and GENI technology are playing a vital role in leading the development of research cyberinfrastructure. The NSF CISE "Looking Beyond the Internet" Steering Group Report identifies GENI as a thought leader for future research infrastructure. Key GENI concepts are increasingly embedded into new projects, and successor mid-scale infrastructure research efforts, such as NSF Future Cloud, Platforms for Advanced Wireless Research (PAWR), and FABRIC, which are actively building upon GENI's success. 

The creation, improvement, and ongoing support of GENI and related infrastructure has engaged an unusually wide range of participants from a cross-section of US institutions. This community has designed and developed GENI technology, deployed GENI on their campuses, employed GENI in their research, and built upon GENI concepts to instantiate new research infrastructure. Many universities apply GENI and related infrastructure in their courses, with the potential to transform totally how experimental computer science is taught and learned.

Perhaps most important to us, the GENI community, is that the newest generation of networking and distributed systems researchers have enthusiastically taken up research leadership roles in an ambitious project of national importance. We congratulate the numerous academic and industrial groups - both Principal Investigators and many graduate students - who have played a role in defining and shaping GENI.

Mark Berman, GENI Project Director
